The board consists of 61 circular spaces arranged in a hexagon, five on a side. Each player has 14 marbles that rest in the spaces and are initially arranged as shown at left.
Play alternates between the players one move at a time, with the black marbles moving first. For each move, a player moves a line of one, two or three one space.
The move can be either in-line (parallel to the line of marbles) or broadside (not parallel to the line of marbles), as illustrated at right.

A player can push their opponentâ€²s marbles which are in an adjacent space to their own with an in-line move only. They can only push if the pushing line has more marbles than the pushed line (three can push two or one; two can push one).
Marbles must be pushed into an open space (i.e. not blocked by a marble of either colour).
The winner is the first player to gain six opposing marbles from the opponent.

Welcome to Abalone 2 Tutorial! You picked the right place to get a glimpse of Abalone game basics and rules. In a few steps we will teach you what is Abalone, what are its differences from other board games and how to play it.\n
To proceed further, please press Next .

Abalone is a classic head-to-head board game for two players. Each player has 14 marbles of the same color at his command, one player owns black marbles and the other owns white respectively.\n
Here you can see the initial position of the marbles at the beginning of the game (also called layout ). It is not the only layout used in Abalone - actually there are plenty of them!

In order to succeed players take turns to move their marbles. Let\'s take a look how to move a single marble first.\n
You can move a single marble to the neighbour cell in any direction . The only condition is that the destination cell should be empty - that is, not occupied by friendly or opponent\'s marble.

In Abalone you can also move a group of marbles , but there are some restrictions. First of all, maximum number of marbles you can move at a time is three . Second, they need to stay on the same line .
The first kind of group move in Abalone is leap . It looks pretty much as single marble move. You can perform a leap in any of four side directions . Each of the destination cells must be empty.
Another kind of move is called push . Your marble can push one or two friendly marbles forward. The destination cell should be empty.
